abstract_sentences.1: There is a growing demand for automatic assessment of spoken English proficiency.
abstract_sentences.2: These systems need to handle large variations in input data owing to the wide range of candidate skill levels and L1s, and errors from ASR.
abstract_sentences.3: Some candidates will be a poor match to the training data set, undermining the validity of the predicted grade.
abstract_sentences.4: For high stakes tests it is essential for such systems not only to grade well, but also to provide a measure of their uncertainty in their predictions, enabling rejection to human graders.
abstract_sentences.5: Previous work examined Gaussian Process (GP) graders which, though successful, do not scale well with large data sets.
abstract_sentences.6: Deep Neural Networks (DNN) may also be used to provide uncertainty using Monte-Carlo Dropout (MCD).
abstract_sentences.7: This paper proposes a novel method to yield uncertainty and compares it to GPs and DNNs with MCD.
abstract_sentences.8: The proposed approach explicitly teaches a DNN to have low uncertainty on training data and high uncertainty on generated artificial data.
abstract_sentences.9: On experiments conducted on data from the Business Language Testing Service (BULATS), the proposed approach is found to outperform GPs and DNNs with MCD in uncertainty-based rejection whilst achieving comparable grading performance.

body_sentences.18: There are, however, computational constraints on training set sizes for GPs.
body_sentences.19: In contrast, Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) are able to scale to large data sets, but lack a native measure of uncertainty.
body_sentences.20: However, Gal and Ghahramani (2016) have shown that Monte-Carlo Dropout (MCD) can be used to derive an uncertainty estimate for a DNN.
body_sentences.21: Alternatively, a Deep Density Network (DDN), which is a Mixture Density Network (Bishop, 1994) with only one mixture component, may be used to yield a mean and variance corresponding to the predicted grade and the uncertainty in the prediction.
body_sentences.22: Similar to GP and DNNs with MCD, a standard DDN provides an implicit modelling of uncertainty in its prediction.
body_sentences.23: This implicit model may not be optimal for the task at hand.
body_sentences.24: Hence, a novel approach to explicitly model uncertainty is proposed in which the DDN is trained in a multitask fashion to model a low variance real data distribution and a high variance artificial data distribution which represents candidates with unseen characteristics.

body_sentences.49: This requires a novel training procedure.
body_sentences.50: Two normal distributions are constructed: a low-variance real (training) data distribution pD and a high-variance artificial data distribution pN, which models data outside the real training data region.
body_sentences.51: The DDN needs to model both distributions in a multi-task (MT) fashion.
body_sentences.52:
The loss function for training the DDN with explicitly specified uncertainty is the expectation over the training data of the KL divergence between the distribution it parametrizes and both the real and artificial data distributions:
L = Ex̂[KL(pD||p(g|x̂;M)] + α · Ex̃[KL(pN||p(g|x̃;M)]
(9)
where α is the multi-task weight.

body_sentences.58: The target variance σ2(x̃) should depend on the similarity of x̃ to the training data.
body_sentences.59: Here, this variance is modelled by the squared normalized Euclidean distance from the mean of x̂, with a diagonal covariance matrix, scaled by a hyperparameter λ.
body_sentences.60: The artificial inputs x̃ need to be different to, but related to the real data x̂.
body_sentences.61: Ideally, they should represent candidates with unseen characteristics, such as L1, accent and proficiency.

body_sentences.109: 5 Conclusions and Future Work  A novel method for explicitly training DDNs to yield uncertainty estimates is proposed.
body_sentences.110: A DDN is a density estimator which is trained to model two distributions in a multi-task fashion (1) the low variance (uncertainty) true data distribution and (2) a generated high variance artificial data distribution.
body_sentences.111: The model is trained by minimizing the KL divergence between the DDN and the true data distribution (1) and between the DDN and the artificial data distribution (2).
body_sentences.112: The DDN should assign its prediction of low or high variance (uncertainty) if the input is similar or dissimilar to the true data respectively.
body_sentences.113: The artificial data distribution is given by a factor analysis model trained on the real data.
body_sentences.114: During training the artificial data is sampled from this distribution.
body_sentences.115: This method outperforms GPs and Monte-Carlo Dropout in uncertainty based rejection for automatic assessment.
body_sentences.116: However, the effect of the nature of artificial data on rejection performance should be further investigated and other data generation methods, such as Variational AutoEncoders (Kingma and Welling, 2014), and metrics to assess similarity between artificial and real training data should be examined.
body_sentences.117: The proposed approach must also be assessed on other tasks and datasets.
